Jesus confronts his audience, asserting that their actions are in direct opposition to Abraham. He refers to himself as a man who has told them the truth from God. This distinction highlights the human sympathy and the honesty of Jesus, who spoke the truth directly from God. The crime of Jesus is simply telling the truth, whereas Abraham, known for love and hospitality, would not have rejected the truth or sought to take someone's life. The stark contrast between the audience's actions and the character of Abraham clearly reveals that they are not true children of Abraham or of God. Jesus, as the Son of Man, does not need to explicitly assert his deity, as his miracles and works clearly demonstrate his divinity.

Jesus boldly confronts his audience, emphasizing the divergence between their actions and Abraham's character. He identifies himself as a man who spoke the truth from God, drawing attention to his human sympathy and the sincerity of his message. In stark contrast, Abraham embraced truth and refrained from taking innocent lives, making their intent to kill Jesus even more heinous. By rejecting the truth and displaying hostility, they proved their lack of kinship with Abraham as well as their opposition to God. Jesus implicitly affirms his divinity through his miraculous works.
